childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1984-1996

The click of a View-Master reel advancing. The chemical smell of Scratch 'n Sniff stickers. The satisfying crunch of a Fruit Roll-Up peeled from its plastic backing. Your childhood had a texture that screens can't replicate—everything was tactile, immediate, real.

At two, the Challenger exploded, and you absorbed adult grief without understanding it. At five, the Berlin Wall fell, and you watched crowds with sledgehammers on a TV you weren't supposed to be watching. At seven, the Soviet Union dissolved, and the Cold War your parents had lived under their entire lives just... ended. You didn't appreciate what that meant. You were busy with your Ninja Turtles.

Your toys were serious business. Transformers that actually transformed—Optimus Prime, Megatron, Soundwave with his cassette minions. He-Man and the Masters of the Universe. She-Ra for the girls who got tired of Barbie's career changes. G.I. Joe with the file cards on the back you memorized like baseball statistics. My Little Ponies with brushable hair that your sister would kill you for touching.

Saturday mornings were sacred. You woke before your parents, poured yourself a bowl of Cookie Crisp or Fruity Pebbles, and planted yourself in front of the TV for four solid hours. The Smurfs, Muppet Babies, Pee-wee's Playhouse, then the Disney Afternoon block—DuckTales, Chip 'n Dale Rescue Rangers, TaleSpin. By the time your parents shuffled out for coffee, you'd absorbed more content than they realized existed.

Friday nights meant Blockbuster. That specific smell—carpet cleaner and plastic VHS cases. Running your fingers along the spines in the New Releases section, hoping nobody had taken The Land Before Time or The Princess Bride. The backup movie that sometimes turned out better than your first choice. Microwave popcorn with too much fake butter. Your whole family on one couch, watching together, because there was only one TV and no one had anywhere else to be.

You ate Lunchables with the pizza kind being premium. Dunkaroos you rationed so the frosting lasted. Gushers that promised to turn your head into a fruit. Hi-C Ecto Cooler in the green box with Slimer on it—you'd fight your siblings for the last one. At eleven, Princess Diana died, and you watched 2.5 billion people mourn someone they'd never met. You didn't understand parasocial grief then. You understand it now.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

Millennial. The word became a punchline before you hit thirty—shorthand for entitled, fragile, participation-trophy collectors who ruined everything from napkins to the diamond industry. Never mind that you're the most educated generation in American history. Never mind that you played by every rule and still got handed a collapsing economy. The narrative was written before you got a chance to speak.

You were seventeen on September 11, 2001. Senior year of high school, or just starting it. You remember the classroom, the teacher's face, the moment someone wheeled in the TV. You watched the second plane hit live. You watched the towers fall. The before and after of that morning split your adolescence in two. Before: Y2K parties, Napster downloads, the promise of a new millennium. After: orange terror alerts, endless wars, shoes off at airports forever.

Your generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. You're the largest living generation, though Gen Z is gaining. You were promised that hard work and education would guarantee success. You got the degrees, took the internships, did everything right. Then you graduated into a crater.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were twenty-four. Not fresh out of college but not established either—that brutal middle ground where you'd just started to feel stable. Jobs evaporated. The housing market imploded. Your parents' retirement accounts vanished. You learned, viscerally, that the system wasn't designed to catch you when it failed.

You're sandwiched between Gen X (who bought houses when houses cost what cars cost now) and Gen Z (who never expected stability in the first place). You still believe, somewhere deep down, that reform is possible. You're not sure why you still believe that. But you do.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Ghostbusters came out the year you were born—Bill Murray deadpanning while fighting supernatural slime, spawning a franchise that would define your toy box. The Terminator promised he'd be back, and he was, when you were seven, with a sequel that made 'Hasta la vista, baby' the most-quoted line in your elementary school. Beverly Hills Cop made Eddie Murphy the biggest star on the planet. Footloose convinced America that dancing in a barn was revolutionary.

Prince's Purple Rain wasn't just an album—it was a cultural event. Your parents saw it in theaters. You'd hear 'When Doves Cry' at weddings for the rest of your life. Madonna emerged that year with 'Like a Virgin,' scandalizing parents everywhere while their kids memorized every word. Van Halen's 'Jump' was inescapable. Bruce Springsteen's 'Born in the U.S.A.' became the most misunderstood anthem in rock history—people heard the chorus and missed the protest.

Your actual pop culture education started with the cartoon renaissance. At two, you were watching Transformers transform—Optimus Prime's death in the 1986 movie might be your first memory of betrayal by a storytelling medium. G.I. Joe taught you that knowing was half the battle (the other half was lasers). He-Man declared his power while you mimicked with a plastic sword. The Smurfs, Care Bears, Rainbow Brite—your toybox was a merchandising goldmine.

At six, you discovered Nickelodeon's new programming block. Double Dare made you want to get slimed. You Are Here helped you feel less alone. By ten, Rugrats premiered, treating kids like they had actual inner lives. Doug captured the anxious inner monologue of childhood. Ren & Stimpy was too weird for your parents to understand but exactly right for you.

High school meant TRL with Carson Daly, the daily countdown that launched boy band careers. Backstreet Boys or *NSYNC—you had to choose sides. Britney vs. Christina. You knew all the moves to 'Bye Bye Bye' even if you'd never admit it now. The Macarena at every school dance until you wanted to scream. 'Who Let the Dogs Out' on infinite loop.

Then emo arrived. Dashboard Confessional made crying seem sophisticated. Fall Out Boy song titles were longer than the songs themselves. My Chemical Romance made black clothes and eyeliner mandatory. Your MySpace profile had an auto-playing song—something by Taking Back Sunday or The Used that perfectly captured your seventeen-year-old angst. You spent hours ranking your Top 8, knowing the social consequences of every placement.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

Apple launched the Macintosh the year you were born. January 24, 1984. The '1984' Super Bowl commercial—the one with the sledgehammer through Big Brother's screen—premiered two days before. You arrived into a world where personal computers were exotic, expensive, and mostly useless for anyone who didn't program. You'd watch them become everything.

At four, your family might have had a VCR—the kind with the flashing 12:00 nobody knew how to fix. At six, you played your first Nintendo games: Super Mario Bros., Duck Hunt with the plastic gun that only worked if you stood close enough. The NES was magic. You begged for new cartridges. You learned to blow on them when they wouldn't load.

At seven, you heard the sound that would define your adolescent internet: the dial-up handshake. That screech-and-static meant you were about to wait three minutes for a single image to load while nobody in the house could use the phone. AOL discs arrived in the mail constantly. Your first screen name was probably embarrassing—something with numbers because your preferred name was taken.

At eleven, Windows 95 changed everything. That startup sound. The rolling hills wallpaper. Solitaire and Minesweeper for hours because there wasn't much else to do yet. The CD-ROM games: Oregon Trail (you died of dysentery), Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego, Encarta Encyclopedia with its videos that took forever to buffer.

AIM arrived when you were thirteen. A buddy list organized by social hierarchy. Away messages crafted like poetry—song lyrics meant something. The door-opening sound when your crush came online. The agony of deciding whether to message first. 'brb,' 'lol,' 'ttyl'—you developed a language your parents couldn't decode.

At sixteen, Napster. Suddenly every song ever recorded was free, if you were willing to wait four hours and risk viruses. You learned to steal music before you could legally buy it. LimeWire after Napster died. Burned CDs with handwritten tracklists. At nineteen, the iPod put 1,000 songs in your pocket. At twenty, Facebook required a .edu email and your parents didn't know it existed. At twenty-three, the iPhone dropped, and everything before it suddenly looked prehistoric.

You're the last generation that remembers life before the internet was in your pocket. You know what it's like to be truly bored, with nothing to scroll. You can read a map, use a card catalog, remember phone numbers. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were two when the Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. Christa McAuliffe was going to be the first teacher in space, and classrooms across America watched live as the shuttle broke apart seventy-three seconds after launch. You were too young to understand, but you absorbed the grief around you—the first national trauma you experienced without comprehending.

At five, the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. Your parents remember exactly where they were—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, strangers embracing. The Cold War that had defined their entire lives ended in a single night of celebration. For you, it was images on a TV you weren't supposed to be watching past bedtime. You didn't understand the stakes. They'd spent decades afraid of nuclear annihilation. You just saw a party.

At seven, the Soviet Union dissolved. The hammer and sickle came down. The 'evil empire' your parents' generation had grown up fearing simply ceased to exist. The world was supposed to be safer now. History was supposed to be over. That narrative lasted about a decade.

At eleven, Oklahoma City. April 19, 1995. Domestic terrorism before we had the vocabulary. 168 people dead, including nineteen children in a daycare. You were in sixth grade. The adults couldn't explain it because they didn't understand it either. This was Americans killing Americans, and nothing in the script prepared anyone for that.

At fifteen, Columbine. April 20, 1999. You were in ninth grade. You probably didn't watch it live—you were in school—but you felt the aftermath. The lockdown drills started. The clear backpacks. The constant low-grade fear that your school could be next. Something fundamental shifted: school wasn't automatically safe anymore.

At seventeen, September 11, 2001. You remember the classroom. The teacher's face. Someone wheeling in the TV. You watched the second plane hit in real time. You watched the towers fall. The adults were crying, and that scared you more than the images. The wars that followed—Afghanistan, then Iraq—began during your senior year and were still going when you turned thirty.

At twenty-four, the financial system collapsed. You were in college or just out, watching the job market evaporate. At thirty-one, marriage equality became law. At thirty-two, Trump won. At thirty-six, a pandemic shut down the world. You've lived through so many 'unprecedented' events that the word has lost meaning. You're numb to it now.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Let's talk about what happened to you. Not what you did wrong—what was done to you.

You graduated college around 2006, give or take. You had maybe two years of normal job market before the 2008 financial crisis incinerated everything. If you were lucky, you'd found your footing. If you weren't, you graduated directly into the worst economy since the Great Depression. Either way, the rules you'd been promised—work hard, get ahead—turned out to be fiction.

Your parents' career path: graduate, get hired, work forty years, get a pension, retire with dignity. Your path: graduate, send 200 applications, take unpaid internship for 'experience,' get entry-level job requiring a master's degree, job-hop every two years because that's the only way to get a raise, no pension, no stability, no security, retirement as abstract concept.

The gig economy wasn't built for you—it was built to extract from you. Uber wasn't freedom, it was desperation with a slick app. 'Be your own boss' meant no benefits, no protections, no safety net. 'Passion' became code for 'we won't pay you fairly.' You were told to love what you do so much you'd do it for free. Many of you did, because there was no alternative.

You've worked in offices with exposed brick and kombucha on tap, where 'unlimited vacation' meant zero vacation because taking time off was career suicide. You've sat through mandatory fun and values workshops and all-hands about culture while executives gave themselves bonuses and laid off your department. You've been told you're 'like family' by organizations that would fire you by email without a second thought.

The cruelest trick was making you believe it was your fault. Not networked enough. Not hustled enough. Not optimized enough. The truth: the game was rigged before you sat down to play. Wages decoupled from productivity in 1973. The social contract between employer and employee was shredded decades before you entered the workforce. You just inherited the bill.

COVID proved you could work from anywhere, which means now you're expected to work from everywhere, always, Slack pinging at midnight, the laptop on your kitchen table that never fully closes. The boundary between work and life isn't blurred—it's gone.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when having a crush meant memorizing their class schedule so you could 'accidentally' walk the same hallway? When getting their phone number was a victory, even though calling meant talking to their parents first? When passing a folded note in class felt dangerously intimate?

You learned to flirt through AIM away messages. Song lyrics that meant something. 'brb' when you weren't actually leaving—just waiting to see if they'd say something first. The heartbreak of watching them go idle. The hope when their buddy icon bounced back. The interpretive analysis of whether 'hey' or 'heyy' or 'heyyy' meant something different.

Tinder launched when you were twenty-eight. By then, you'd already had relationships the old-fashioned way—meeting at parties, through friends, in college classes, at bars where you actually talked to strangers. The app changed everything. Suddenly courtship was a sorting algorithm. Swipe right, swipe left, reduce humans to a few photos and a bio. You adapted because that's what you do, but something was lost.

You're the bridge generation in dating. You remember when meeting online was embarrassing, something you'd lie about at weddings. ('We met through friends.') Now it's the default. Your Gen Z cousins have never known anything else. Your parents still don't quite understand how any of it works.

You've delayed marriage, not because you don't want partnership, but because the math doesn't work. Average wedding: $30,000. Average house: you can't afford one. Student loans: still paying. The life timeline your parents followed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—isn't available at any price. You're not immature. You're priced out.

Your friendships span time zones now. You've moved for jobs, for school, for cheaper rent. You maintain relationships through group chats that have been active for a decade, where nobody needs to explain the context because you all lived it together. You know how to stay close to people who are far away. You've had to learn.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three economic collapses before you turned forty. The dot-com bust when you were sixteen—you watched your parents' tech stocks evaporate. The 2008 financial crisis when you were twenty-four—you watched the job market crater just as you needed it. COVID when you were thirty-six—you watched everything shut down, again. Each one taught you the same lesson: the floor can disappear at any moment, and nobody's coming to catch you.

Your grandparents saved because they remembered the Depression. Your parents spent because they trusted abundance. You save because you've seen both strategies fail. Your relationship with money isn't rational—it's trauma response dressed up as financial planning.

The numbers are brutal. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control 7%. They bought houses for two years' salary. A median home now costs six times the median income. They got pensions—actual defined benefits that paid them until they died. You got 401(k)s and the advice to 'just invest in index funds' while rent eats 40% of your paycheck.

You graduated with an average of $30,000 in student debt—for a degree you were told was mandatory for the middle class. The interest compounds while you make minimum payments because there's nothing left after rent, utilities, health insurance, car payment, groceries. You'll be paying this debt into your forties. Maybe fifties. The math was never mathing.

The avocado toast discourse wasn't just insulting—it was gaslighting. The idea that your financial struggles stem from $8 breakfast items, not from housing costs that tripled while wages stayed flat. Your parents' generation could buy a house on a middle-class salary. You cannot. That's not a lifestyle choice. That's math.

You've redefined success by necessity. Homeownership isn't the goal—it's a fantasy you've largely abandoned. Retirement at 65 isn't the plan—it's a hope you're not counting on. You're not building generational wealth; you're trying not to become a burden to your kids, if you can afford to have them. Financial security means something different when the system extracts from you instead of building with you.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You're so good at adapting that you've forgotten adaptation isn't the goal. You've optimized your resume, your LinkedIn, your morning routine, your sleep score, your macros, your meditation minutes. You treat systemic problems as personal productivity challenges. The housing crisis isn't a policy failure—it's a budgeting problem you can spreadsheet your way out of. Except you can't. Some problems don't yield to optimization.

Your coping mechanisms have become invisible to you. You call it self-care when it's actually survival. You call it hustle culture when it's actually exploitation you've accepted. You've normalized things that should be outrageous: healthcare tied to employment, education requiring debt, retirement as fantasy. The water you swim in is toxic, and you've stopped noticing the taste.

Irony is your native language, and it's limiting you. You can't just like something—you have to like it ironically, or critique it while consuming it, or distance yourself with a self-deprecating joke. Earnestness feels dangerous. Advocacy feels cringe. You hedge everything because sincerity makes you vulnerable. This makes it hard to fight for what you actually want.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be team players, to bring solutions not problems, to never rock the boat. You'll accept 'that's just how it is' as an explanation. You'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance. You've mistaken accommodation for maturity.

The digital world feels like action, but it's often just performance. You can mobilize for causes on Twitter, but voter turnout in local elections—where policy actually changes—lags far behind the engagement metrics. You can cancel celebrities, but changing zoning laws requires showing up to boring city council meetings. The dopamine hit of righteous posting isn't the same as power.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you blame yourself. You've internalized the failure narrative so thoroughly that you forget the system was designed this way. You didn't fail to buy a house. The housing market failed you. You didn't fail to save enough. Wages failed to keep up with costs. The self-improvement industry exists because it's easier to sell you a fix than to fix the system. You're not broken. The world you inherited is.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2004-2014): This was supposed to be the decade of finding yourself. Instead, it was the decade of surviving. You graduated into reasonable job markets, then watched the 2008 crisis incinerate everything. You took jobs you were overqualified for, moved back home or crammed into apartments with four roommates, watched friends who'd done everything right end up bartending and driving for Uber. The life script your parents followed (graduate, get job, get married, buy house, have kids) wasn't available at any price. You delayed everything. Not because you weren't ready—because the math didn't work.

Your 30s (2014-2024): This decade was about picking up the pieces. You probably made more money than you did at 25, but it didn't feel like more. Rent went up. Groceries went up. The goalposts moved while you were running. You watched Gen Z enter the workforce with TikTok side hustles and no expectation of stability, and you weren't sure if they were smarter than you'd been or more broken. You were supposed to 'settle down,' but settled felt like a trap. You built something—you just weren't sure what.

Your 40s (2024-2034): You're entering this decade now. Statistically, this will be your peak earning period. You'll have authority at work, clarity about what you want, maybe some acceptance of what you can't change. If you have kids, they'll be getting older, needing less of your physical presence and more of your wisdom (such as it is). Your parents will be aging, needing more. You'll be sandwiched—managing up and down, responsible for generations on either side. Some of you will double down on the life you've built. Some of you will blow it up and start over. Both choices are valid.

Your 50s (2034-2044): You'll be pre-retirement age with no expectation of retiring. You'll have lived through at least four economic crises, probably two pandemics, and so many 'once in a generation' events that the phrase lost meaning years ago. You'll mentor younger people who can't imagine a world before smartphones, and you'll catch yourself saying things like 'you don't understand' and hating how you sound. You'll be annoyed at their naivety and jealous of it in equal measure.

Your 60s and beyond (2044+): Retirement, if it exists for you, won't look like your grandparents' version—the pension, the gold watch, the decades of leisure. It'll be part-time work, gig economy participation, reliance on systems that may or may not still exist. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable. And you'll tell younger people what it was like before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was connected. You'll tell them about Blockbuster Friday nights and dial-up modems and calling your friends' houses. They won't believe you. It'll sound like science fiction in reverse.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

3.7 million people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest living generation, at least for now. Gen Z is catching up.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): You got the same degrees, but they got jobs that paid enough to live on. They bought houses in their twenties. You're still renting in your forties. They had pensions; you have 401(k)s and the vague hope that Social Security won't collapse before you're seventy. They came of age during economic expansion; you came of age in economic crater. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control 7%. A house in 1975 cost about two years of median income. Now it's six. They bought their forever home at 28; you're paying half your income in rent and being told to stop buying coffee. They lecture you about fiscal responsibility from houses that appreciated 400% while they slept.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You remember the before times. They don't. You still believe, somewhere deep down, that the system can be reformed. They know it's broken and are building around it. You adapted to smartphones as young adults; they were born with iPads in their hands. You have nostalgia; they have nihilism. Neither of you has savings.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years—slightly lower than previous generations, thanks to rising 'deaths of despair' (suicide, overdose, alcoholism). Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, which is treated as a personal failing rather than a rational response to irrational conditions.

But you've also made the world genuinely better. You normalized therapy. You destigmatized mental health struggles. You pushed for marriage equality and racial justice and trans rights in ways your parents' generation refused to. You inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. The economy is rigged against you, but the culture shifted because you showed up. That matters.

year_events: Apple Macintosh launched with iconic '1984' Super Bowl ad
Ronald Reagan re-elected in landslide victory
Band Aid recorded 'Do They Know It's Christmas?'
